pullRequest.body:
Ported lemmas from `Data/Nat/Multiplicity` to into a new file called `Data/Nat/Factorization/Multiplicity`, re-written in terms of `factorization`.

Also, I'm new to this so is it fine to have a lemma copied over from another file? Like, I copied over 

@[simp]
theorem Prime.factorization_self {p : â„•} (hp : Prime p) : p.factorization p = 1 := by simp [hp]

from Dat/Nat/Factorization/Basic.

---

> Hi - sorry for the delay! I should be able to take another look today/tomorrow:)

No worries. I really appreciate you doing this!

Here's a couple of comments - I'll try to come back to this PR later this week:) 
1) If possible, it would be worth trying to move some of the results from the file you added to `Data.Nat.Factorization.Basic`, just so that they are usable with less imports
2) There seem to be some duplicate results, e.g `multiplicity_choose_aux` appears in both the new file and in `Data.Nat.Multiplicity`. I would suggest removing the versions in the latter, and making `Data.Nat.Multiplicity` import `Data.Nat.Factorization.Multiplicity`. 
3) Arguably, we probably want to derive the results in `Data.Nat.Multiplicity` using the results you've added in this PR - would you mind adding a TODO note? (this can probably be left to a future PR)

Here's a couple of comments - I'll try to come back to this PR later this week:) 
1) If possible, it would be worth trying to move some of the results from the file you added to `Data.Nat.Factorization.Basic`, just so that they are usable with less imports
2) There seem to be some duplicate results, e.g `multiplicity_choose_aux` appears in both the new file and in `Data.Nat.Multiplicity`. I would suggest removing the versions in the latter, and making `Data.Nat.Multiplicity` import `Data.Nat.Factorization.Multiplicity`. 
3) Arguably, we probably want to derive the results in `Data.Nat.Multiplicity` using the results you've added in this PR - would you mind adding a TODO note? (this can probably be left to a future PR)
Rather than duplicating lemmas, it's best to reuse existing lemmas - in your case, one way to to so would be to add an import to your new file.
Thanks for the comment. I just thought importing the entire basic file just to use one lemma was bad pratice.

One stylistic point: typically, we would write
```
have : foo := by 
  tac1
  tac2
```
rather than 
```
have : foo := by  {
  tac1
  tac2
}
```
and so on.

Note that you should be able to avoid using new lemmas such as `factorization_mulâ‚€ ` by using already existing API for `factorization` and `Finsupp`. 
```suggestion
_ = (n + 1).factorization p + (n !).factorization p := by
        rw [factorization_mul (zero_ne_add_one n).symm (factorial_ne_zero n), coe_add, Pi.add_apply]
```
One useful trick for finding such lemmas when you're writing proofs is to use the `simp?` tactic.

You can actually prove this results using  `factorization_eq_card_pow_dvd` and the following result
```
theorem find_me_a_name {n p b : â„•} (pp : p.Prime) (hn : n â‰  0) (hb : n < p ^ b) :
    {i âˆˆ Ico 1 n | p ^ i âˆ£ n} = {i âˆˆ Ico 1 b | p ^ i âˆ£ n} := sorry
```
I think it would also be better to find another name for `factorization_eq_card_pow_dvdâ‚€` (e.g. maybe something along the lines of `factorization_eq_card_pow_dvd_of_lt`?).

```suggestion
  simp [factorization_pow, Prime.factorization_self hp]
```
Here, it would be better to follow the [style guidelines](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html) for indentation:)

```suggestion
  rcases h with âŸ¨k, rflâŸ©
  simp [factorization_mul hb (Nat.ne_zero_of_mul_ne_zero_right hc)]
```

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Algebra.GeomSum
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Digits
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Factorization.Basic
```
You can find this smaller set of imports by running `#min_imports` at the bottom of your file.
Oh, that's a neat trick.

```suggestion
theorem Ico_pow_dvd_eq_Ico_of_lt {n p b : â„•} (pp : p.Prime) (hn : n â‰  0) (hb : n < p ^ b) :
    {i âˆˆ Ico 1 n | p ^ i âˆ£ n} = {i âˆˆ Ico 1 b | p ^ i âˆ£ n} := by
  ext i
  simp only [Finset.mem_filter, mem_Ico, and_congr_left_iff, and_congr_right_iff]
  refine fun h1 h2 â†¦ âŸ¨fun h â†¦ ?_, fun h â†¦ lt_of_pow_dvd_right hn (Prime.one_lt pp) h1âŸ©
  rcases p with - | p
  Â· rw [zero_pow (not_eq_zero_of_lt h2), zero_dvd_iff] at h1
    exact  (hn h1).elim
  Â· refine LE.le.trans_lt (le_log_of_pow_le pp.one_lt ?_) ((lt_pow_iff_log_lt pp.one_lt hn).mp hb)
    obtain âŸ¨k, rflâŸ© := h1
    exact Nat.le_mul_of_pos_right ((p + 1) ^ i)
      (zero_lt_of_ne_zero <| Nat.ne_zero_of_mul_ne_zero_right hn)
```

```suggestion
  rw [factorization_eq_card_pow_dvd n hm2, Ico_pow_dvd_eq_Ico_of_lt hm2 (not_eq_zero_of_lt hn)]
  exact lt_pow_of_log_lt (Prime.one_lt hm2) hb
```

```suggestion
theorem factorization_factorial {p : â„•} (hp : p.Prime) :
    âˆ€ {n b : â„•}, log p n < b â†’ (n !).factorization p = (âˆ‘ i âˆˆ Ico 1 b, n / p ^ i : â„•)
  | 0, b, _ => by simp
  | n + 1, b, hb =>
    calc
      ((n + 1)!).factorization p = (n + 1).factorization p + (n !).factorization p := by
        rw [factorial_succ, factorization_mul (zero_ne_add_one n).symm (factorial_ne_zero n),
          coe_add, Pi.add_apply]
      _ = #{i âˆˆ Ico 1 b | p ^ i âˆ£ n + 1} + (âˆ‘ i âˆˆ Ico 1 b, n / p ^ i : â„•) := by
        rw [factorization_factorial hp ((log_mono_right <| le_succ _).trans_lt hb), add_left_inj]
        apply factorization_eq_card_pow_dvd_of_lt hp (zero_lt_succ n) hb
      _ = (âˆ‘ i âˆˆ Ico 1 b, (n / p ^ i + if p ^ i âˆ£ n + 1 then 1 else 0) : â„•) := by
        simp [Nat.add_comm, sum_add_distrib, sum_boole]
      _ = (âˆ‘ i âˆˆ Ico 1 b, (n + 1) / p ^ i : â„•) :=
        Finset.sum_congr rfl fun _ _ => (succ_div _ _).symm
```

```suggestion
  rw [factorization_prod hS, finset_sum_apply]
```
I'd suggest `factorization_prod_apply` as a name for this lemma. This and `factorization_pow_self` would be more at home in `Mathlib.Data.Nat.Factorization.Basic`.
This theorem and the one below would be natural to put in `Data/Nat/Factorization/Basic`, e.g. below `factorization_eq_card_pow_dvd`.
If I move it to Basic, it would require me to import `import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Digits`. Is that fine?

```suggestion
  induction' n with n ih
  Â· simp
  Â· simp only [factorization_factorial_mul_succ hp, ih, factorial_succ,
      cast_add, cast_one, â†add_assoc, factorization_mul (zero_ne_add_one n).symm
      (factorial_ne_zero n), coe_add, Pi.add_apply]
    ring
```

```suggestion
  rw [factorization_factorial hp (Nat.lt_add_one (log p n))]
  exact Nat.geom_sum_Ico_le hp.two_le _ _
```

```suggestion
  rw [â†factorization_choose' hp ((Nat.sub_add_cancel hkn).symm â–¸ hnb), Nat.sub_add_cancel hkn]
```

Here's a couple of comments - I'll try to come back to this PR later this week:) 
1) If possible, it would be worth trying to move some of the results from the file you added to `Data.Nat.Factorization.Basic`, just so that they are usable with less imports
2) There seem to be some duplicate results, e.g `multiplicity_choose_aux` appears in both the new file and in `Data.Nat.Multiplicity`. I would suggest removing the versions in the latter, and making `Data.Nat.Multiplicity` import `Data.Nat.Factorization.Multiplicity`. 
3) Arguably, we probably want to derive the results in `Data.Nat.Multiplicity` using the results you've added in this PR - would you mind adding a TODO note? (this can probably be left to a future PR)
